Many measures that could reduce the burden of disease (e.g., use of cleaner fuels, judicious use and management of toxic substances, and better hygiene measures) might progress more quickly if individuals used the tools of scientific literacy to inform evidence-driven decision-making. With the support of the National Science Foundation, the Breathe, Eat, Touch (BET) project focused on using topics within environmental health to transform undergraduate education in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) and create a well-trained citizenry that understands the intersection of natural sciences and the mathematical science of public health (epidemiology).

The BET project has teaching, increased access, and accessibility at its core. We began development by surveying undergraduates to identify topics of interest to them. We then used their interests to develop and offer a course based upon cases investigating the chemistry, biology and epidemiology within exposure to second hand smoke, air pollution, pesticides, PCBs, antibacterial treatments, and sun screen. These topics were paired with service learning projects in which students applied their knowledge to develop resources for community partners. Our second offering of the course used refined cases paired with four-week laboratory units that augmented the inquiry-based learning through experimental design, data collection and analysis, and discussions of the broader implications of the research. To increase portability and transferability, the learning resources are modular and exercises were developed using readily available, low cost resources.

STEM disciplinary knowledge was advanced within our institution as each investigator participated in pedagogical faculty development workshops and worked together intensively to develop modules where the contributions and interactions of different areas of expertise were highlighted. The project included team-teaching and resulted in significant cross-disciplinary training for the faculty involved; cross-training that directly resulted in modules incorporated into pre-existing undergraduate courses so that they more fully integrate aspects of biology and chemistry, two faculty members each offering an interdisciplinary courses for high school students, and a successfully joint-laboratory research program that has provided research experiences for sixteen undergraduate researchers.

We have shared findings from our BET project survey and our rationale and approach to the teaching and scientific communities at a variety of scientific meetings. A module that introduces case method teaching approaches has been published and the six content modules and three laboratory units are freely available on our project website.

 


Last Modified: 02/23/2017
Modified by: Karen K Bernd
